newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Wall Street high-tech jolt to Asia seen fleeting.
newsitem.headline: Wall Street high-tech jolt to Asia seen fleeting.

text.p: Prices of Asian high-tech shares rose on Wednesday, tracking an overnight surge of electronic shares on Wall Street, but analysts said the jolt was unlikely to spur a longer-term rise.

If history is a guide, they said, Asia's key high-tech markets in Taiwan, South Korea and Japan likely would pay more heed to various local factors while also remaining hampered by a current slump in global computer memory chip prices.

Widespread gains by technology shares, including an all-time high for International Business Machines Corp and a surge by chip giant Intel Corp, pushed the Dow Jones industrial average to a record finish of 7,383.41 on Tuesday.
The jump spurred correlative gains by major Asian firms.
South Korea's largest chipmaker, Samsung Electronics Co, rose 2,100 won ($2.35) to 63,500 on Wednesday.
In Taiwan, the electronics sector rose 0.78 percent while the overall index lost 0.80 percent to 8,058.46 points.
Taiwan's top chipmaker, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, gained T$5 (18 cents) to T$116 while another major chipmaker, Mosel Vitelic Inc rose T$3 to close at T$63.50.

"The timing was just right. Wall Street made a jump and those (Taiwan) shares that had seen some previous profit-taking had room for a corresponding rise," said David Yu, vice president of Taipei's International Investment Trust.
"But the boost is probably only temporary, and most of the electronic shares remain somewhat overvalued," Yu added.
High-tech shares in Japan also rode the wave of the Dow rise. Fujitsu Ltd added 10 yen (nine cents) to stand at 1,390 by the end of morning trade.
Pioneer Electronic Corp, benefitting from a rebounding profit outlook, gained 140 yen to 2,720 by midday.
"Until now, the shares were considered to be a loser," one broker said. "However, the firm is expected to come back into the black, and investors are appreciating the forecast."
Pioneer said last week that it expected a parent current profit of 4.8 billion yen in fiscal 1997/98, compared to a loss of 4.10 billion yen the previous year.
In South Korea, analysts said the chip industry remained plagued by sluggish global prices despite Wednesday's gains by Samsung, Hyundai Electronics and LG Semicon.
"I cannot see any reason to revise our forecast upward for (Korean) semiconductor companies," said Ssangyong Securities analyst Bahn Young-one.
Hong Jong-hyun of Coryo Securities said: "New York's rally helped semiconductor shares gain further momentum, but it would be a temporary boost."
Bahn said the unit price for 16-megabit dynamic random access memory chips on the spot market will average a low $8-$9 in 1997.
In Taiwan, analysts warned that electronics' index-defying rise may hurt the market by drawing too much money into one single sector at the expense of the market's overall health.
"All the funds were concentrated too heavily in electronic stocks, especially integrated-circuit shares," said Yu of International Investment Trust.
"Such a disparity meant that confidence in the market was weak other than in just the one sector," he said.

The electronic sector fielded the lukewarm session's five most heavily traded shares. Chipmaker Winbond Electronics Corp, which notched the session's highest trade volume at 84.7 million shares, dropped T$0.90 to T$38.
